Hello,
<Lurker mode off>
I'm happy to see the discussion begin. As a professional QA person with ov=
er 20 years hand-on experience it is my sad duty to report that the schema =
for testing being discussed is a set-back to quality. It is the case that q=
uantity is the current goal in software development. The trend to go live a=
nd debug after customers start calling support is real. Developers should d=
o their unit testing, of course. The problem is (especially in Agile method=
s) the time for QA has been cut drastically. The need for integration testi=
ng is greater than ever before, but the time QA has for that activity is re=
duced to such short periods that that type of testing is relegated to last,=
 IMHO.
=20
As an example, using the Agile method (scrums, sprints) where a sprint of =
28 days is in place code is not ready for testing until maybe the 21 day. I=
n my experience the project managers for sprints do not understand the need=
 for engineering specs, hence they do not exist, or if they do they are aft=
er the fact. There is no time in the plan for rework of bad code. There is =
no time in the sprint for rigorous QA. This leads to quantity not quality. =
I admit I read this group because we use Java (moving to .net) and I wish I=
 had the time to learn the tools you provide. Perhaps in the future. Until =
that time and even beyond great unit testing is only and input/output type =
of test. Remember that satellite that crashed in the planet Mars because di=
fferent methods of measuring speed were used. Effective integration testing=
 would have caught that problem.
=20
Allowing developers the time to create good code is a partnership with QA =
- allowing them the time to effectively test it. Is it a waste of time...as=
k the customers if they want products that work or products that meet the g=
oals of project managers.
=20

C=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 wrote:

> The reason why you can't let either group own 100% of the tests is becau=
se
> they each come with their own bias/limitations:
>=20
>    - Developers tend to test only what they think their software does.
>    - QA testers can overlook testing tricky parts of the code because
>    either the functional specs or their understanding of the code is not
>    exhaustive.

In many cases, when programmers don't test their own code, they deliver=20
such low quality work that testers spend their time writing and running=20
trivial test cases, driving out silly bugs, rather than being allowed to=
=20
spend their time writing interesting tests, driving out the kinds of=20
bugs that drive customers crazy.
